title: Loss, Grief & HIV

content: We all face loss when it comes to HIV. With everything that happens after testing positive, there’s a lot of change, loss, and grief we have to face. Head-on.

What’s usually most difficult is letting go of what was. That doesn’t mean there’s an automatic erasure of your life before HIV. But parts of your life and identity do change, and there’s no way to get around that.

Most of what you experience after being diagnosed involves change. As you adapt to the new and unfamiliar, it’s natural to mourn the life you knew. As challenging as it might feel, leaning into this part is the best thing you can do. How you identify, what your daily routines are, and your overall outlook on life will be affected. You’re allowed to feel your feelings about things changing.

Accepting your new reality can be complicated. A form of grieving happens. It can manifest in various ways, but most common are its impacts both mentally and emotionally. You may experience stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. Remember, this isn’t permanent, despite how lasting it may feel.

content: Grief and loss can also impact your relationships with other people. As much as we’re affected by HIV, so are those closest to us. This looks different for each person, depending on your circumstances and the quality of those relationships.

If you’re lucky, your connections with your loved ones will strengthen and deepen, and you’ll feel more loved and supported by them. But for many, their relationships aren’t so supportive. If you meet hurtful reactions or others pull away, allowing yourself to feel any grief or loss is all that you can do.

The good news is that beyond the grief and loss, there’s hope and opportunity. Reshaping your life can be scary, but it’s also one of the most rewarding and empowering things that can happen. As you begin to figure out who you are, and how your life operates with HIV, it’s possible to develop a newfound sense of strength and resilience.

content: These will help you face everything that comes your way.

When I was juggling all of these conflicting emotions, I found it got easier with practice and the passage of time. And then, without me even realizing it, something happened. I went from living in a constant state of worry and panic, to having a sense of enthusiasm and optimism.

With each year after my diagnosis, I felt more confident and capable of facing whatever was to come. That’s because I’d survived what felt like the absolute worst thing that could happen, contracting HIV.

Experiencing grief and loss in life is inevitable. Often, it’s a moment-to-moment process we figure out as we go. When it comes to HIV, loss and grief can feel all-consuming and impossible to overcome.
But on the other side of what was, you can experience even more life, including everything meaningful that you feared HIV would take from you.
